document_title: Amazon Web Services: Q4 results show reaccelerating growth driven by AI workloads
document_content: Amazon Web Services (AWS) reported Q4 2024 revenue of $27.5 billion, up 19.3% year-over-year (16.9% constant currency), marking acceleration from 12.3% growth in Q1. Operating income reached $10.4 billion with operating margin of 37.8%, up from 29.8% a year ago, demonstrating strong operational leverage. The reacceleration was driven by three key factors: (1) generative AI workloads contributing an estimated $2.5 billion in quarterly revenue, growing 140% YoY; (2) optimization tailwinds abating as customers completed cloud spend rationalization; and (3) new customer wins in enterprise and public sector. Management noted that AI-related revenue is growing from a smaller base but represents the fastest-growing workload category. AWS's AI infrastructure advantage includes custom silicon (Trainium, Inferentia chips), which offers 40% better price-performance vs GPU alternatives for certain workloads. The company has secured large multi-year commitments from AI-native companies, including Anthropic, Stability AI, and Hugging Face. Traditional compute and storage segments showed stabilization, with database services (Aurora, RDS) growing 25% and analytics (Redshift, EMR) up 18%. Edge computing and CDN services (CloudFront) expanded 22%. Internationally, AWS grew 23% in EMEA, 27% in APAC, and 15% in Americas. Competitive dynamics remain intense, with Microsoft Azure and Google Cloud both investing heavily in AI capabilities. AWS maintained its market leadership at approximately 32% share, though Azure gained share in AI-specific workloads. Looking ahead, management guided Q1 2025 AWS revenue to $28.5-29.0 billion, implying 18-20% growth. Full-year 2025 capex is expected to exceed $75 billion, with majority allocated to AWS infrastructure for AI and compute capacity. Key investment considerations: AWS remains the profit engine for Amazon, contributing over 60% of total operating income despite representing only 16% of revenue. The AI opportunity is substantial but competitive, requiring continued heavy investment in infrastructure and silicon development.

metadata.author: Brian Fitzgerald, CFA, Internet & Cloud Analyst

expected_summary: AWS reported Q4 revenue of $27.5B (+19.3% YoY, +16.9% constant currency), accelerating from Q1's 12.3% growth. Operating income reached $10.4B with margin of 37.8% (up from 29.8% YoY), showing strong leverage. Growth drivers: (1) GenAI workloads ~$2.5B quarterly revenue (+140% YoY), (2) optimization headwinds abating, (3) new enterprise wins. AWS's AI advantage includes custom silicon (Trainium, Inferentia) offering 40% better price-performance. Secured large commitments from Anthropic, Stability AI, Hugging Face. Traditional segments stabilizing: databases +25%, analytics +18%, edge computing +22%. Geographic growth: EMEA +23%, APAC +27%, Americas +15%. Market share ~32%, though Azure gaining in AI workloads. Q1 2025 guidance: $28.5-29.0B (+18-20%). FY2025 capex >$75B, mostly for AWS AI infrastructure. AWS contributes 60% of Amazon operating income on 16% of revenue.

Regional performance: EMEA +23%, APAC +27%, Americas +15%. AWS maintains ~32% market leadership despite Azure's AI workload share gains. Q1 2025 guidance of $28.5-29.0B implies 18-20% growth.
